trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised controlled trial of non-invasive cardiac output monitoring in the emergency room:
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial of non-invasive cardiac output monitoring on oxygen delivery in critically ill emergency department patients.

conditions.healthcondition: Critical illness in the emergency department requiring urgent administration of at least 500ml intravenous fluid

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Diseases of the vasculature and circulation including the lymphatic system

interventions.interventions: Subjects will be allocated to standard care plus non-invasive cardiac output monitoring (intervention). Non-invasive cardiac output monitoring for four hours in the Emergency Department (ED).
interventions.comparator: Standard care for the presenting illness without cardiac output monitoring.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Lactate levels as measured by blood gas analysis
Base excess as measured by blood gas analysis
Vital signs (heart rate and blood pressure)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Questionnaire regarding clinicians management plans for each patient, before and after cardiac output monitoring.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Critically ill adults in the ED requiring referral to Intensive Care for consideration of admission.

trial_design.concealment: Patients requiring urgent fluid administration will be randomised to having this guided by non-invasive cardiac output monitoring where stroke volume variation will be used to guide resuscitation or to standard care
trial_design.sequence: Allocation will be by computerized random number generation

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Box Hill Hospital Nelson Road Box Hill Vic 3128

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Suite 5B, The Terrace Suites, 19 Lang Parade, Milton Qld 4064

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Critically ill patients often have signs of inadequate oxygen delivery. We know this adversely impacts on survival. The hypothesis is that the introduction of non invasive cardiac output monitoring will allow us to improve or correct oxygen delivery, thus possibly improving survival

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Human research Ethics Committee The Prince Charles Hospital

contact.name: Dr Ogilvie Thom
contact.address: Emergency Department, Princess Alexandra Hospital, Ipswich road, Wolloongabba, QLD
